awd_titl_txt: INSPIRE: Adaptive Multi-Scale Modeling of Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
This INSPIRE project is jointly funded by the Plasma Physics and Computational Physics programs in the Physics Division in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, the Magnetospheric Physics program in the Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences Division in the Directorate for Geosciences, and the Office of Integrative Activities.  Ionized gas, or in scientific terms plasma, is the most common state of matter in the Universe. In the solar system, for example, the solar corona where solar eruptions occur, the solar wind that carries the erupted plasma and magnetic field from the Sun to the Earth, the magnetosphere surrounding the Earth and protecting us from the harmful effects of the eruption, and the ionosphere through which radio communications and GPS signals propagate and get disturbed, all consist of plasma. Understanding plasma is crucial for predicting and mitigating the effects of space weather. Plasmas also play an important role in engineering, for example in the design of fusion type reactors that promise to provide an inexhaustible source of clean energy for humanity. Computational modeling of plasma dynamics is very challenging due to the different spatial and temporal scales and the complex behavior of the system. The project is aimed at improving the efficiency of present plasma simulation models by a factor of 1000 or even more. If successful, the new model will provide accurate and affordable simulations for systems that currently cannot be modeled even on the largest supercomputers.

There are different approaches for plasma modeling that all have advantages and drawbacks. The most accurate kinetic methods describe all the important effects of plasma by describing the full distribution function in a six dimensional phase space, but they have tremendous computational cost. Even on today's supercomputers, modeling a large three-dimensional system with kinetic methods is far out of reach. Alternative fluid-type methods describe the plasma distribution function with a handful of moments, such as density, velocity and pressure. Solving for these quantities in addition to the magnetic field can be done quite efficiently, and in fact one can model the solar corona, the solar wind, and the magnetosphere with global fluid models with reasonable computational resources. Unfortunately, in most systems there are some parts of the domain where the fluid description is not sufficient, and this can have consequences for the global solution. The project aims at combining the kinetic and fluid type methods in an adaptive and dynamic fashion. The expensive kinetic model will be restricted to the small parts of the domain where the fluid description is not accurate enough, while the efficient fluid methods will be employed in the vast majority of the domain. This hybrid approach promises to provide accurate solutions at a tiny fraction of the cost of the fully kinetic models. A speed up of factor of 1000 or even more is expected. This will allow modeling global plasma systems with unprecedented accuracy and vastly improve our understanding and predictive capabilities.

por.por_cntn:
Our project has achieved a breakthrough advance in the multi-scale modeling of plasma systems. Plasma physics starts from the kinetic electron scales and goes up to the size of the system of interest that is often many orders of magnitude larger. Traditional computational tools employ a single type of model to describe the whole system. One approach, magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) uses a simplified fluid-like description of the plasma, which can capture large scale phenomena efficiently. Another approach, particle-in-cells (PIC), can provide accurate solution for the small scale phenomena at a very high computational cost. When the separation of small kinetic scales and the global system size is large, this monolithic approach does not work at all, or gives inaccurate results, or has unreasonably high cost. Our group has pioneered the MHD with Embedded PIC (MHD-EPIC) method that can overcome this issue. The INSPIRE grant enabled major improvements and applications of this new method.

On the theoretical side, we have shown in a careful study that one can artificially increase the kinetic scales and still get physically correct solutions as long as the increased kinetic scales remain well-separated from the global scales. This approach can save several orders of magnitude improvement in computational speed. Our new Gauss? Law satisfying Energy Conserving Semi-Implicit Method (GL-ECSIM) conserves both energy and electric charge and eliminate instabilities and spurious oscillations, so one can get accurate results in long simulations. Finally, we have developed and implemented the MHD with Adaptively Embedded PIC (MHD-AEPIC) algorithm that can dynamically change the location of the PIC region as needed. MHD-AEPIC can further reduce the computational cost by about an order of magnitude relative to MHD-EPIC using a static PIC box. We have devised a simple, accurate and efficient way of identifying regions where magnetic reconnection is likely to occur. In addition, we have developed and implemented a new six-moment fluid solver that has more physics than MHD but more efficient than PIC. 

In terms of software development, the GL-ECSIM scheme was added into the original iPIC3D model, the Adaptive Mesh Particle Simulator (AMPS) and the brand new Flexible Exascale Kinetic Solver (FLEKS). The latter combines GL-ECSIM with new particle splitting and merging methods and the open-source AMReX library for adaptive gridding. All three PIC models are part of the Space Weather Modeling Framework (SWMF) and are coupled to the MHD code BATS-R-US. Both AMPS and FLEKS can be used with adaptive embedding. AMPS includes the physics of collisions and chemical reactions, while FLEKS has a lean and flexible software design that makes it easy to use and provides excellent performance on large super computers.

The new methods and codes outlined above have been used to model the magnetic reconnection producing flux transfer events (FTEs) at the dayside magnetopause of Earth and Ganymede, showing good agreement with in situ satellite observations by the MMS and Galileo spacecraft, respectively. We have also modeled the dynamic reconnection in the magnetotail of Mercury, Mars and Earth and compared our results with the MESSENGER, MAVEN and THEMIS missions, respectively. The good agreement between the simulations and observations suggest that the MHD-EPIC model can successfully capture the essential physical processes. Having a full three-dimensional time-dependent solution allows us to understand the dynamics of these systems in unprecedented detail. 

We studied the periodic plasmoid formation in the magnetotail of Earth during strong but steady solar wind driving, the so called sawtooth events. Our model could reproduce this phenomenon without including ionospheric outflow in the system. This is in sharp contrast with prior work that relied on simpler MHD model to approximate the reconnection process and  required a complicated ionospheric outflow model to reproduce the sawtooth oscillations. We showed that capturing the kinetic reconnection physics is sufficient to produce the ~1 hour period and the characteristic features of the oscillations. This is quite remarkable, as the kinetic temporal scales are much shorter than 1 hour. Our model also suggests that the tail reconnection is much more complex than previously thought. Instead of a single reconnection line, there is a patchwork of several reconnection lines that form, evolve, and disappear in a complex dynamic fashion.

We also studied the reconnection at the dayside magnetopause and found similar complexity in the processer producing FTEs. The model shows several reconnection lines most of the time. These lines grow longer and move towards the cusps roughly with the flow speed of the magnetosheath. The FTEs occur between these reconnection lines and their structure changes as they evolve. This suggests that the different FTE types observed are simply FTEs at different evolutionary stages.

This project provided funding and exciting research topic for several graduate students and post docs for five years. It provided major contribution to two completed theses and the developed methods and tools are actively used by several current graduate students.
